questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of intermittent episodes of pain in all her fingers bilaterally. The episodes are worse during the winter. The fingers become white when exposed to cold weather, then severely painful and numb once they warm up. She has started wearing gloves at all times to prevent these episodes. She has generalized anxiety disorder. Her mother has systemic lupus erythematosus. Current medications include lorazepam and fluoxetine. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 127/78 mm Hg. Examination of both hands shows no abnormalities. Allen test is negative. Her hemoglobin concentration is 14.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,800/mm3, and platelet count is 156,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Nailfold capillary microscopy is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are contraindicated in patients with RP because they lead to further vasoconstriction of the arteries and worsen the vasospasms caused by the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin may be administered for erythromelalgia in polycythemia vera (PV). Although erythromelalgia often mimics RP, the pathophysiology differs. RP is caused by vasospasms, whereas erythromelalgia is caused by microvascular thrombosis due to hyperviscosity. This patient does not present with signs of PV (e.g., constitutional symptoms, plethora, pruritus) and her blood cell counts are not elevated, which excludes PV.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical nitroglycerin is only used in severe courses of therapy-resistant secondary RP (e.g., necrosis of finger tips) or if first-line treatment is poorly tolerated or contraindicated.

D) CORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers, in particular oral nifedipine, are the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with primary RP because of their vasodilatory effect. Initial treatment should also include conservative measures, such as avoidance of triggers (e.g., cold, stress), smoking cessation, and discontinuation of vasoconstrictive drugs that may cause vasospasms (e.g., triptans).

Nailfold capillary microscopy can help distinguish primary RP from secondary disease. While primary RP is caused by idiopathic vasospasms of the digital arteries and arterioles and is not associated with vascular changes seen on nailfold capillary microscopy, patients with secondary RP typically have structural vascular changes caused by the underlying disease (e.g., systemic sclerosis), such as enlargement and/or loss of capillaries.
Image Description:

There is white discoloration of second to fifth fingers of both hands, extending from the fingertips to the distal or proximal interphalangeal joints.

E) INCORRECT:

Epoprostenol may be administered for pulmonary hypertension and cases of severe and resistant RP. It is typically administered intravenously. This patient does not have any signs of severe disease (e.g., ulcers) and has not received any first-line agents yet, which means that epoprostenol is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppressants such as prednisone can be used to treat certain systemic conditions associated with secondary RP, e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and scleroderma. While this patient has a family history of SLE and should therefore be examined carefully for this condition, she does not have other features of systemic disease. Moreover, secondary RP is caused by vasospasm due to arteriolar changes in the fingers (and/or toes), which manifests with an abnormal capillaroscopic pattern on nailfold capillary microscopy. This patient's presentation is consistent with primary RP, for which prednisone is not indicated.
questions.hint: Pain and discoloration of the fingers following exposure to cold suggests Raynaud phenomenon. A normal nailfold capillary microscopy is consistent with primary Raynaud phenomenon (RP).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but has had several episodes of “finger pallor” over the past 4 months. During these episodes, the 4th finger of his left hand turns white and feels numb. The color usually returns within 20 minutes, followed by redness and warmth of the finger. The episodes are mildly painful. The complaints most commonly occur on his way to work, when it is very cold outside. Once, it happened when he was rushing to the daycare center because he was late for picking up his daughter. The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with lansoprazole. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. The blood flow to the hand is intact on compression of the ulnar artery at the wrist, as well as on compression of the radial artery. When the patient is asked to immerse his hands in cold water, a change in the color of the 4th digit of his left hand is seen. A photograph of the affected hand is shown. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.2 g/dL, serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 35 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin is a treatment option for polycythemia vera (PV), which is also associated with RP. However, this patient's hemoglobin is normal and further symptoms of PV, such as plethora or pruritus are missing. Aspirin may be indicated in patients with secondary RP who are at risk for digital ulceration or thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies can be useful for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome, which is associated with paresthesias of the fingers. However, color changes secondary to arterial vasospasm are not characteristic of carpal tunnel syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate peripheral arterial occlusion associated with tissue ischemia and vasospasm. However, this patient does not have any risk factors for peripheral artery disease (e.g., smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia). Instead, the transient and reversible nature of this patient's vasospasm suggests another underlying process. Also, a negative Allen test indicates patent arterial circulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography can help diagnose peripheral arterial occlusion, which may be associated with tissue ischemia and vasospasm. However, this patient does not have any risk factors for peripheral artery disease (e.g., smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia). Instead, the transient and reversible nature of this patient's vasospasm suggests another underlying process. Also, a negative Allen test indicates patent arterial circulation.

E) CORRECT:

RP is commonly seen in individuals with autoimmune conditions such as connective tissue diseases (e.g., systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, mixed connective tissue disease) and vasculitides (e.g., Buerger disease). Therefore, patients with suspected secondary RP should receive further workup for these conditions, including serologic testing for antinuclear antibodies and rheumatoid factor. Additional causes of secondary RP include exposure to vibration, certain drugs (e.g., beta blockers), hyperviscosity syndromes (e.g., polycythemia vera), and smoking. Patients with secondary RP are at risk of tissue injury, including digital pitting, ulceration, and gangrene, due to critical ischemia (see “Primary vs. secondary Raynaud phenomenon” table).

This patient's history of gastroesophageal reflux disease raises concern for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Topical vasodilators such as nitroglycerin are a second-line therapy for primary RP and are used in treatment-resistant disease, not for initial management. Calcium channel blockers, especially nifedipine, are the pharmacotherapy of choice for primary RP. In this patient, secondary causes of RP should be ruled out before initiating treatment as these would warrant treatment of the underlying condition.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sequential discoloration of the fingers (pallor followed by hyperemia) triggered by cold and emotional stress. His asymmetrical attacks, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), male sex, and onset at > 40 years of age make secondary Raynaud phenomenon (RP) likely.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain. The pain occurs intermittently in 5-minute episodes. It is not conclusively brought on by exertion and sometimes occurs at rest. He has a history of hyperlipidemia and takes a high-dose statin daily. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 67 years and his mother has type 2 diabetes. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. He has no chest wall tenderness and pain is not reproduced with palpation. While waiting for laboratory results, he has another episode of chest pain. During this event, an ECG shows ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF that are > 1 mm. Thirty minutes later, a new ECG shows no abnormalities. Troponin I level is 0.008 ng/mL. Cardiac angiography is performed and shows a 30% blockage of the proximal right circumflex artery and 10% blockage in the distal left circumflex artery. This patient's condition is most closely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is commonly associated with hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking, as in this patient, and it often coincides with coronary artery disease. However, this patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is not associated with PAD.

B) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is commonly associated with hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking, as in this patient, and it often coincides with coronary artery disease. However, this patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is not associated with erectile dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Stroke is commonly associated with hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking, as in this patient, and it often coincides with coronary artery disease. However, this patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is not associated with stroke. Even though these vasospasms likely affect cerebral circulation as well, they are not severe enough to cause a stroke.

D) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is commonly associated with hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking, as in this patient, and it often coincides with coronary artery disease. However, this patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is not associated with T2DM.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertension is commonly associated with hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking, as in this patient, and it often coincides with coronary artery disease. However, this patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is not associated with hypertension.

F) CORRECT:

Raynaud phenomenon is caused by an exaggerated vasoconstrictive response of the digital arteries and arterioles to cold or emotional stress. Raynaud phenomenon typically manifests with a sequential discoloration of fingers and/or toes, from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reactive hyperemia). This patient most likely has vasospastic angina, which is associated with other vasospastic disorders, such as Raynaud phenomenon.

The vascular theory of migraine postulates that dilation and vasoconstriction of intra- and/or extracranial vessels contribute to the development of migraine symptoms, such as headache and aura. While this theory is no longer widely supported, vasospasm may still play a role in the development of migraines and there may be an association of vasospastic angina with migraine.
Image Description:

There is white discoloration of second to fifth fingers of both hands, extending from the fingertips to the distal or proximal interphalangeal joints.
questions.hint: A combination of reversible ST elevations, normal troponin levels, and a cardiac angiography showing ≤ 30% coronary artery blockage makes vasospastic angina (Prinzmetal angina) the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain. What other condition is associated with vasospasm?

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of episodic, bilateral finger pain and discoloration that occurs with cold weather. Her fingers first turn white, then blue, before eventually returning to a normal skin color. The symptoms have been occurring daily and limit her ability to work. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. She does not smoke. Physician examination shows normal capillary refill of the nail beds. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is a cardioselective β1-receptor blocker that is used for the treatment of various conditions, including heart failure, hypertension, and supraventricular tachycardia. Although β1-selective blockers are less likely to cause vasoconstriction (compared to nonselective beta blockers), beta blockers should generally be avoided in patients with Raynaud phenomenon as they increase the risk of further attacks.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is a direct sympathomimetic agent that causes vasoconstriction via its effects on alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. It is used for ophthalmologic procedures (causes mydriasis) as a nasal decongestant and for the treatment of patients with severe hypotension or priapism. Because of its vasoconstricting effects, phenylephrine should be avoided in patients with Raynaud phenomenon.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrates, such as isosorbide dinitrate, cause vasodilatation via the release of nitric oxide by vascular endothelial cells. Nitrates can be used to treat patients with acute coronary syndrome, angina, and pulmonary edema. Topical isosorbide dinitrate is only used in severe cases of therapy-resistant secondary Raynaud phenomenon (e.g., necrosis of the fingertips) or if first-line treatment is poorly tolerated or contraindicated.

D) CORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers, such as oral nifedipine, are first-line pharmacotherapeutic treatment for patients with (idiopathic) primary Raynaud phenomenon (Raynaud disease) because of their vasodilatory effect. Initial treatment should include conservative measures, such as avoidance of triggers (e.g., cold, stress.)

In patients with features of secondary Raynaud phenomenon, which include unilateral presentation, arthralgias, myalgias, and/or digital ulcerations, workup for possible underlying etiologies (e.g., autoimmune disease, vasculitis, or arterial disease) would be warranted.
Image Description:

There is white discoloration of second to fifth fingers of both hands, extending from the fingertips to the distal or proximal interphalangeal joints.

E) INCORRECT:

Ergot alkaloids, such as ergotamine, cause vasoconstriction via their effects on 5-HT1 receptors and alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. Ergotamine is used for the treatment of acute migraine headaches. Ergot alkaloids should generally be avoided in patients with Raynaud phenomenon as they increase the risk of further attacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids, such as prednisone, express their anti-inflammatory effects via inhibition of NF-κB and phospholipase A2. Prednisone may be used to treat patients with secondary Raynaud phenomenon due to an underlying condition (e.g., Sjögren syndrome, systemic sclerosis, or systemic lupus erythematosus.) This patient, however, lacks signs of systemic disease.
questions.hint: This young woman's painful and discolored fingers are classic symptoms of primary Raynaud phenomenon, which is caused by vasospasms in the digital arteries and arterioles usually triggered by cold temperature or stress.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents for follow-up 3 months after being diagnosed with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis on the basis of Raynaud phenomenon, skin thickening and tightening (sclerodactyly) of her hands and feet, a positive anticentromere antibody test, and esophageal dysmotility.
At today’s visit, she notes that her Raynaud phenomenon has worsened significantly, particularly in cold weather. She is having frequent painful episodes involving all digits of her right hand and the third digit of her left hand. She has been avoiding caffeine, has quit cigarette smoking, and is keeping warm when outside by wearing mittens, hats, and layers.
On examination, her vital signs are unremarkable. All of the digits on the right hand and the third digit on her left hand are pale and tender distal to the proximal interphalangeal joints (figure). She has no ulcers on the fingertips and has 2+ radial pulses bilaterally. Tight sclerotic skin distal to her wrists and ankles is evident bilaterally. During the course of the visit, her fingertips begin to return to their normal color.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) nor hydrochlorothiazide are indicated for treating Raynaud phenomenon.

B) INCORRECT:

A phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, such as sildenafil, would be an appropriate pharmacologic treatment to try if calcium-channel blockers are ineffective, but sildenafil is not considered first-line therapy, in part because of its high cost.

C) INCORRECT:

Although angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, such as ramipril, are an important treatment for scleroderma renal crisis, the evidence for effectiveness in Raynaud phenomenon is weaker.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) nor hydrochlorothiazide are indicated for treating Raynaud phenomenon.

E) CORRECT:

A dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for symptomatic Raynaud phenomenon in patients for whom supportive measures (for example, wearing mittens and avoiding caffeine) are no longer adequate. The medications used most commonly include nifedipine (extended-release formulation) and amlodipine.

Key learning point: In patients with systemic sclerosis who have symptomatic Raynaud phenomenon despite supportive measures, the first-line pharmacologic treatment for the Raynaud phenomenon is a calcium-channel blocker, such as nifedipine or amlodipine.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports that for the past 15 years, she has experienced white and blue discoloration of her fingers when she goes outside in cold weather. She has never had digital ulceration or prolonged episodes lasting more than 30 minutes after rewarming her digits. She has occasional knee pain but no joint swelling or morning stiffness. A systems review is negative. She states that she has no history of blood clots, miscarriages, oral ulcers, alopecia, chest pain, fevers, abdominal pain, dysphagia, skin thickening, photosensitive rash, dry eyes, or dry mouth.
Physical examination is unremarkable. She has no digital ulcers, callus formation, or tapering of the digits. Digital nail-fold capillaroscopy is normal. There is no skin thickening or loss of range of motion in her fingers.
Laboratory testing reveals normal findings for complete blood count, kidney function, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein level. Antinuclear antibodies are detected at a titer of 1:80.
Which one of the following tests, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Clinical observation only; no further testing at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-scleroderma-70 and anticentromere antibody tests, if positive, would suggest diffuse or limited systemic sclerosis. However, these tests are not warranted in a patient whose history and examination suggest benign primary Raynaud phenomenon and who has no skin abnormalities or other symptoms that suggest systemic sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody test would suggest small-vessel vasculitis, but this test is not warranted in the absence of symptoms suggesting vasculitis in the fingers or elsewhere.

C) CORRECT:

In a young, healthy woman with Raynaud phenomenon who has normal levels of inflammatory markers, no aggressive Raynaud complications (e.g., digital ulcers or ischemic crises), no other features of connective tissue disease, no other causes of vascular injury to the digits, normal digital nail-fold capillaroscopy, and long-standing disease with onset in the teenage years, the most likely diagnosis is primary Raynaud phenomenon. As many as 10% of healthy women test positive for antinuclear antibodies at a titer of 1:80, making it a nonspecific finding that does not require any further testing or treatment.

All patients with Raynaud phenomenon (whether primary, as in this case, or secondary to a connective tissue disease or other cause) should be counseled about maintaining an adequate core body temperature by wearing layered clothes appropriate for the season. In addition, many medications, toxins, and environmental causes can exacerbate Raynaud phenomenon and should be avoided as much as possible; these include tobacco smoke, marijuana smoke, cocaine, amphetamines, beta-blockers, caffeine, and psychosocial stress.

Key learning point: Low-level positive antinuclear antibody tests in the absence of other features of connective tissue disease do not require any further testing or treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

An antiphospholipid antibody test is unnecessary in a patient without a history of blood clots, digital necrosis, or miscarriages who does not have features that raise suspicion for systemic lupus erythematosus.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-scleroderma-70 and anticentromere antibody tests, if positive, would suggest diffuse or limited systemic sclerosis. However, these tests are not warranted in a patient whose history and examination suggest benign primary Raynaud phenomenon and who has no skin abnormalities or other symptoms that suggest systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of episodic digital color changes. She describes her fingers turning white, then blue, then red. These seem more common when she's stressed or if she forgets her gloves when walking the dog. Episodes last approximately 30 minutes and occur several times weekly. She had not been concerned until she saw a TikTok suggesting this was a sign of lupus. Physical examination shows normal pulses and blood pressure readings in both arms and no systemic features of disease. A photograph of her hands is shown. Which finding would most strongly suggest the need for further autoimmune evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Thumb involvement during Raynaud episodes is characteristic of secondary Raynaud phenomenon and indicates the need for autoimmune evaluation. In primary Raynaud phenomenon, the thumb is typically spared, making thumb involvement a key distinguishing feature that suggests underlying connective tissue disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Onset after age 30 is associated with secondary Raynaud phenomenon, however, this patient is 28 years of age. Other features are more specific for secondary Raynaud phenomenon.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral symmetric involvement is common in both primary and secondary Raynaud phenomenon. This finding alone does not distinguish between the two types or indicate the need for autoimmune evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Episodes in both primary and secondary Raynaud phenomenon can last 15–20 minutes or longer, with some potentially lasting several hours. Duration alone is not a reliable distinguishing feature between primary and secondary causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Frequency of episodes varies in both primary and secondary Raynaud phenomenon and depends on trigger exposure. Episode frequency alone does not differentiate between primary and secondary causes.
